Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Report February,2011  Sales/Trading Statement Results on Mar 03, 2011
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report February, 2011  sales/trading statement results on Mar 03, 2011

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Announces Compounding Tamiflu Oral Suspension for Children
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that with flu activity on the rise and now widespread in 44 states according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a spike in demand for the suspension (liquid) form of Tamiflu for children has resulted in a shortage of the flu-fighting drug. In response, the company pharmacies in all 50 states are prepared to compound Tamiflu capsules into the liquid form to continue filling oral suspension prescriptions without interruption. Tamiflu capsules remain in adequate supply. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has established an approved method for compounding Tamiflu, creating a liquid mixture that ensures the most effective and proper dosing. Walgreens pharmacists are trained in compounding and have the necessary ingredients to begin producing Tamiflu Oral Suspension from capsule form upon depletion of the manufacturer's supply. Tamiflu is the most widely-prescribed antiviral flu medicine for both children and adults. All Walgreens and Take Care Clinics continue to offer flu shots daily with no appointment necessary.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Announces Retirement of Hal F. Rosenbluth as President of Health and Wellness Division
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that Hal F. Rosenbluth will retire as President of its Health and Wellness division in April, but will continue with the company as a senior consultant to the CEO for health care services. Rosenbluth was a co-founder of Take Care Health Systems, which was acquired by Walgreens in 2007. Prior to that, he led Rosenbluth International, a global travel management company, which he sold to American Express in 2003.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Announces Executive Changes
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. has made several executive promotions and appointments recently. Sona Chawla, who had been senior vice president of e-commerce, has been elevated to president of e-commerce. In addition, Walgreens has promoted Robert Zimmerman, who had been vice president of corporate development, to senior vice president and chief strategy officer. The promotion recognizes the increasing importance of strategy development at Walgreens as well as Zimmerman's contributions in leading business development, mergers and acquisitions, strategy development and planning. Finally, Mia Scholz, who had served as vice president of accounting and controller, has been moved up to senior vice president. Walgreens has gone outside the chain drug industry in hiring Graham Atkinson to fill the post of senior vice president and chief customer experience officer. He is responsible for developing and leading the company's loyalty strategies, with a specific emphasis on the customer experience. Atkinson, who reports to Wasson, spent 20 years in marketing, customer experience, sales and operations at United Airlines, where he was president of Mileage Plus.

Key Development Headline: HCA, Inc. Approves Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation
Key Development Situation:
HCA, Inc.'s Board of Directors has approved amended and restated certificate of incorporation, an increase in the number of authorized shares of common stock from one hundred twenty-five million (125,000,000) to one billion right hundred million (1,800,000,000), as reflected in 
amended and restated certificate of incorporation, the adoption of the 2006 Stock Incentive Plan for Key Employees of HCA Holdings, Inc. and its Affiliates, as Amended and Restated (the Stock Incentive Plan) and subsidiary HCA Inc.'s Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation.

Key Development Headline: Amedisys Inc. Appoints Julie L. Lewis as Vice President of Health Policy and Government Relations
Key Development Situation: Amedisys Inc. announced that Julie L. Lewis will serve as Vice President of Health Policy and Government Relations. In this new role, Ms. Lewis is assisting the company in the continued development of a patient-centered, value-driven agenda for effective chronic disease management and end-of-life care that focuses on the quality and sustainability of the U.S. health care system. Ms. Lewis works with hospitals, physicians, and private payers to develop pilots to test new delivery and payment models for post-acute, palliative, and chronic disease care. She also sits on the National Quality Forum's National Priorities Partnership on behalf of the Alliance for Home Health Quality and Innovation. Prior to joining Amedisys, Ms. Lewis served as the Director of Health Policy at the Dartmouth Institute (TDI) for Health Policy and Clinical Practice in Hanover, New Hampshire. Ms. Lewis managed the health policy team at TDI, which focuses on payment reform, quality improvement in the delivery system, and population health measurement. Ms. Lewis also served as lead staff for the collaboration between TDI and the Brookings Institution and was the director of the Accountable Care Organizations (ACO) project, which included implementation of five pilots around the country, development of a starter set of performance measures, and data analysis of current spending and growth trends.

Key Developments by Type: Executive/Board Changes - Other; Executive Changes - CFO
Key Development Headline: HCA, Inc. Announces Executive Appointments
Key Development Situation: The Board of Directors of HCA, Inc. appointed R. Milton Johnson as the President and Chief Financial Officer of the company effective February 9, 2011. Mr. Johnson previously served as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company since July 2004 and was appointed as a director in December 2009. The Board of Directors of the company appointed Samuel N. Hazen as the President of Operations of the company effective February 9, 2011. Mr. Hazen previously served as President of Western Group since July 2001.

Key Development Headline: HCA, Inc. Announces Internal Reorganization; Announces Management Changes
Key Development Situation:
HCA, Inc. announced an internal reorganization, effective immediately, designed to better align the company's structure with the future dynamics of the healthcare industry. The changes include: the creation of a new subsidiary that will provide business services to other healthcare companies; a new structuring of provider operations; and a further integration of clinical quality performance with physician practice services.

Beverly B. Wallace, who reports to Johnson and most recently was President of HCA's Shared Services Group, becomes President of a new wholly-owned subsidiary, which is anticipated to provide revenue cycle, staffing services and supply chain management to other healthcare providers. Also as part of the reorganization, the company's Chief Medical Officer, Dr. Jonathan B. Perlin, expands his role to include responsibility for HCA affiliated physician practices. This new alignment better integrates physician practices with the organization's overall clinical and quality operations. Perlin's new title is President of HCA's Clinical and Physician Services Group.

Key Development Headline: HCA, Inc. Names George Bussey as Chief Medical Officer
Key Development Situation: HCA has named George Bussey chief medical officer for its HealthOne division, which includes the Nashville-based hospital system's Colorado operations. Bussey will lead clinical and quality initiatives supporting consistent high-quality clinical performance and practice standards" across HealthOne hospitals in Denver, as well as HCA hospitals in Oklahoma City and Edmond, Okla. and Wichita, Neb. Previously, Bussey was senior vice president and chief medical officer at FirstHealth of the Carolinas in Pinehurst, N.C.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Report January,2011 Sales/Trading Statement Results on Feb 03, 2011
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report January, 2011 sales/trading statement results on Feb 03, 2011

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. and Daryl Groom Launch Colby Red Through Walgreens Drugstores
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. and Daryl Groom launched Colby Red, a new table wine dedicated to raising awareness for heart disease. Colby Red is being sold through collaboration with Walgreens. Full roll-out to more than 4,500 Walgreens locations is expected during American Heart Month in February. The 2009 Colby Red is a flavorful California cuvee of cabernet sauvignon, zinfandel, shiraz, merlot and petite sirah from select Treasury Wine Estates vineyards, retailing for $12.99. Groom was inspired to create the wine in honor of his 12-year old son, Colby Rex Groom, who was born with a hole in his heart and has undergone multiple surgeries to treat the defect. Colby was first diagnosed with a heart defect when he was born. By the age of 2, the atrial septal defect, or "hole," had healed itself but doctors quickly found a defective heart valve. When Colby was 8, with his heart leaking and deteriorating, the family decided to have him undergo open-heart surgery to repair the valve. When that repair did not hold, Colby received a St. Jude Medical mechanical heart valve. The association with St. Jude Medical Foundation resulted in a commitment from Daryl and his wife, Lisa, and later Colby, to support education and research for children's cardiac care so parents will not have to endure the fear, distress and uncertainty the family experienced while Colby was being diagnosed and treated.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Launches Exclusive BORBA Skin Care Collection
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that the new 'Inside Out Beauty Solutions' collection by BORBA is available exclusively at select Walgreens stores nationwide and on Walgreens.com. The new line of skin care "cosmeceuticals," supplements and ingestible products are aimed at enhancing skin's youthful appearance through innovative solutions including topical cleansers and moisturizers, vitamin-enhanced water and dietary supplements like fruit or vitamin chews. The collection was developed by celebrity esthetician Scott Vincent-Borba, pioneer of the "superfruit skin care movement." Superfruits are a class of foods known for their very high nutrient or antioxidant content. Among them are the acai berry, blueberry, pomegranate, cranberry and grape seed. Borba's skin care and ingestible formulations include a number of superfruits to help defend cells against the free radical damage that can lead to premature aging, illness or even disease. The new collection consists of 27 products: Nine clinically-tested skin care products including Age Defying 4-in-1 Cleansing Treatment, Age Defying Wrinkle Smoothing Serum and PMS Skin Rescue 7-Day Treatment System ranging from $9.99 to $24.99. A 5-piece Age Defying Starter Kit available for $24.99 offers customers an easy, affordable way to try BORBA skin care. Nine dietary supplements including Firm & Fit Calcium Chews, Healthy Glow Immunity Drink Mix and Mighty Energy Gummi Mice ranging from $14.99 to $19.99. Four vitamin-enhanced Skin Balance Water formulas and four corresponding Skin Balance Crystalline drink mixes ranging from $1.99 to $6.99.

Key Developments by Type: Executive/Board Changes - Other; Executive Changes - CEO
Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Announces Executive Changes
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced the next stage of its transition plan outlined during its Annual Shareholders meeting last year. After the successful transition of day-to-day responsibilities for the company's retail operations earlier this month, the company has announced that Larry Merlo, President and Chief Operating Officer of the company, will assume the role of CEO effective March 1, 2011. Thomas M. Ryan will remain Non-Executive Chairman until his retirement at the company's Annual Meeting of Shareholders in May of 2011. The company also announced that upon Ryan's retirement as Chairman in May 2011, its intention is to elect David Dorman as the next Non-Executive Chairman of the Board of Directors of CVS Caremark at the 2011 Annual Meeting. Dorman has been on the the company Board of Directors since 2006.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Approves to Amend the Articles of Incorporation
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. held its annual meeting of shareholders on January 12, 2011. At the annual meeting, the proposal to amend the Articles of Incorporation to revise the purpose clause was approved, the proposal to amend the Articles of Incorporation to eliminate certain supermajority vote requirements was approved and the proposal to amend the Articles of Incorporation to eliminate the ‘fair price’ charter provision applicable to certain business combinations was not approved (proposal required the affirmative vote of 80% of the company’s outstanding shares as of the record date). Following shareholder approval at the company’s AGM of the amendments to the company’s Articles of Incorporation, the company filed Articles of Amendment to its Articles of Incorporation with the Secretary of State of Illinois. The Charter Amendments became effective on January 18, 2011 upon filing of the Articles of Amendment. The Charter Amendments amended the purpose clause to permit the company to engage in any or all lawful acts or activities for which corporations may be incorporated under the Illinois Business Corporation Act of 1983, as amended, and eliminated certain super-majority vote requirements.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Announces Management Changes
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark announced that it has appointed its two highest ranking retail executives to jointly lead its CVS/pharmacy business, reporting directly to Larry Merlo, President and Chief Operating Officer of CVS Caremark. Effective immediately, Mike Bloom, executive vice president Merchandising and Supply Chain, and Scott Baker, executive vice president Internal Operations and Real Estate, will take over the management of the company's retail business for its 7,100 stores across the country. Bloom and Baker are assuming these responsibilities on an interim basis. Mike Bloom is a seasoned retail executive with more than 30 years of retail experience, 20 of them with CVS/pharmacy. As the senior CVS/pharmacy executive with direct oversight for merchandising and supply chain activities, Bloom leads an integrated end-to-end network managing store layout as well as the selection, purchasing, inventory and supply of product throughout the company's retail locations as well as managing the company's visual merchandising and pricing departments. In addition to his current role, Bloom will now assume responsibility for advertising and marketing. Scott Baker, whose tenure with CVS/pharmacy spans more than 25 years, has held a variety of important senior roles including senior vice president of retail operations and head of the company's East retail field operations. Baker, a pharmacist by training, will now assume responsibility for all of the company's retail field organizations and pharmacy operations.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Announces Executive Appointments
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that Graham W. Atkinson is joining the company as senior vice president and chief customer experience officer, effective Jan. 24. Atkinson will be responsible for developing and leading the company's loyalty strategies with a specific emphasis on the customer experience. He will report to President and Chief Executive Officer Greg Wasson. Sona Chawla, currently senior vice president of e-commerce, is promoted to president of e-commerce. Mia Scholz, currently corporate vice president of accounting and controller, is promoted to senior vice president of accounting and controller. Robert Zimmerman, currently vice president of corporate development, is promoted to senior vice president and chief strategy officer in recognition of the increasing importance strategy development plays at Walgreens and his contributions leading business development, mergers and acquisitions, strategy development and planning.

Key Development Headline: North Carolina Pharmacies Sues CVS Caremark
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark has been sued by North Carolina pharmacies, which have alleged that CVS violated the North Carolina Pharmacy of Choice Act, as well as committing unfair and deceptive business practices. The plaintiffs in the lawsuit, three independent pharmacies, have accused CVS of obtaining patient information from independent pharmacies and then using that information to cause patients to purchase their medicine at CVS. The independent pharmacies also allege that CVS's "Maintenance Choice" program is designed such that it requires patients to fill their prescriptions for maintenance medications only at CVS-owned retail and mail pharmacies, or else be denied coverage and reimbursement.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Releases a New National Research Study
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. released a new national research study showing that nearly half of patients currently using mail order pharmacy for 90-day supplies of prescription medications are unaware that their community pharmacy is an option, despite an overwhelming majority's desire for face-to-face interaction with their pharmacist and for the choice of where their prescriptions are filled. In response, the company is launching an initiative to educate eligible prescription customers about their options to get a 90-day supply of medication at their local Walgreens pharmacy. While many pharmacy benefit plans allow for a 90-day medication supply from local community pharmacies, plan members often aren't aware of this option. In the research, prescription customers also expressed a strong desire to have the ability to receive 90-day supplies of their chronic medications at their community pharmacy: nearly half of mail order pharmacy users believe that mail is their only option for 90-day prescriptions; two-thirds of 30-day chronic medication users would be extremely or very likely to switch to 90-day supplies at their community pharmacy if given the option.
Business Wire: Business Wire; Seeking Alpha; Transcript Collection

Key Developments by Type: Announcements of Earnings; Corporate Guidance - New/Confirmed; Business Expansions
Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Reports Unaudited Consolidated Earnings Results for the First Quarter Ended November 30, 2010; Provides Capital Expenditure Guidance for the Full Year of Fiscal 2011 ; Plans to Open New Stores in Second Quarter of Fiscal 2011
Key Development Situation:
Walgreen Co. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended November 30, 2010. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $17,344 million, operating income of $941 million, earnings before income tax provision of $921 million and net earnings of $580 million or $0.62 per basic and diluted share against net sales of $16,364 million, operating income of $797 million, earnings before income tax provision of $776 million and net earnings of $489 million or $0.49 per basic and diluted share for the same quarter last year. Net cash provided by operating activities was $1,165 million against $1,168 million for the same quarter last year. Additions to property and equipment were $273 million against $304 million for the same quarter last year. The company invested $1 billion in capital expenditures, $1.1 billion in Duane Reade, including exemption of debt and $252 million in file buys and other acquisitions.

The company expect capital expenditures for the full year of fiscal 2011 to be about $1.4 billion.

In the first quarter the company opened about 60 fewer stores than last year while next quarter the company expect to equal last year’s pace for store openings.

Key Development Headline: Health Management Associates Inc. Announces Amendments to By-Laws
Key Development Situation: On December 7, 2010, the Board of Directors of Health Management Associates Inc. amended and restated the company’s By-laws to provide that stockholders must generally provide notice of a proposal or nomination of a person for election to the Board at any annual meeting not earlier than the 120 day, and not later than the 90 day, prior to the anniversary of the preceding year’s annual meeting. If the annual meeting is held more than 30 days before or 60 days after such anniversary date, notice must be delivered not later than the close of business on the later of the 90 day prior to the annual meeting or the 10 day following the day on which the company first makes public disclosure of the date of the meeting. Under the Bylaws, stockholders seeking to submit a proposal or nomination for consideration at a meeting of stockholders must also provide information with respect to their record and beneficial ownership of the company’s stock, hedging transactions with respect to the company’s stock, proxy or voting agreements with respect to the company, transactions or proposed transactions with the company, litigation against the Company or its officers, directors and any affiliates, and stock holdings in any of the company’s competitors as well as information regarding the other business or nominee the stockholder proposes to bring before a meeting of the stockholders. As a result of the adoption of the By-laws, if any stockholder intends to provide notice of a proposal except for proposals made pursuant to Rule 14a-8 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 or nomination of a person for election to the Board at the 2011 Annual Meeting of Stockholders, such stockholder’s notice must be received by the company’s corporate Secretary at the principal executive office of the company not earlier than January 17, 2011 and not later than the close of business on February 16, 2011.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Blocks Hiring of New CVC President
Key Development Situation: Wal-Mart has sued CVS Caremark Corp. to stop the drugstore chain from hiring its former executive vice president, Hank Mullany, as president of CVS/pharmacy, and a judge has temporarily barred him from joining the company. CVS s hiring of Mullany, 52, former president of Wal-Mart s northern U.S. division, would violate a non-compete agreement, Wal-Mart said in the complaint filed Dec. 3 in Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington. Judge Travis Laster issued an order blocking Mullany from taking his new post until after a Dec. 15 court hearing. Mullany, hired by Wal-Mart in 2006, oversaw operations at 587 Wal-Mart stores in 13 states. He was privy to Wal-Mart s national strategies and responsible for implementing those strategies, lawyers for the Bentonville. The company and Mr. Mullany believe the allegations in the lawsuit are without merit and intend to aggressively defend the lawsuit.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Announces Executive Changes
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark announced that it has appointed Hank Mullany as President of CVS/pharmacy effective December 6, 2010. Mullany, 52, is a seasoned retail executive with nearly thirty years of retail experience and a strong background in operations, finance and strategic planning. Previously as EVP and President of Walmart North, Mullany was responsible for the operation of 1,300 stores across 19 states. Earlier in his career, Mullany served in various senior management positions, including as President of Genuardi's Family Markets in Pennsylvania. Mullany succeeds Merlo who continued to hold responsibility for CVS/pharmacy retail operations while the search for a successor was ongoing.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Announces Change of CEO
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced as part of a corporate succession plan last May 2010, Ryan plans to retire from his position as CEO prior to the next annual meeting at which time Merlo will succeed Ryan as CEO.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Report November, 2010 Sales/Trading Statement Results on December 03, 2010
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report November, 2010 sales/trading statement results on December 03, 2010.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Proposes Amendment to the Articles of Incorporation
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. proposed to amend the articles of incorporation to revise the purpose clause; to eliminate certain supermajority vote requirements; and to eliminate the 'fair price' charter provision applicable to certain business combinations at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held on January 12, 2011.

Key Development Headline: LHC Group Announces Promotion of Donald D. Stelly to President and Chief Operating Officer
Key Development Situation: LHC Group, Inc. announced that Donald D. Stelly, formerly Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, has been promoted to President and Chief Operating Officer of the company. Mr. Stelly has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer since June 1, 2009. Prior to serving as the company's Chief Operating Officer, Mr. Stelly served as the company's Senior Vice President of Operations. Mr. Stelly joined the company in April 2005 after serving as the Chief Executive Officer at Doctor's Hospital. Mr. Stelly's career includes serving as Chief Operating Officer and Chief Nursing Officer of Doctor's Hospital, which was nationally recognized for service excellence and superior operating results, and providing direct patient care as a Registered Nurse in a variety of settings within the healthcare continuum. He earned a Bachelor's Degree in Nursing from the University of Southwestern Louisiana in 1991.

Key Development Headline: ProLogis Provides 645,000 Square Feet of Distribution Space to Walgreens in Pennsylvania
Key Development Situation: ProLogis announced it signed a fourth-quarter lease agreement for 510,000 square feet of previously unleased space and a 135,000-square-foot build-to-suit expansion in Pennsylvania with Walgreen Co. Walgreen will occupy a total of 645,000 square feet at ProLogis Park 33 Building One in Easton, Pennsylvania. The company will move into the existing, 510,000-square-foot space during the fourth quarter of 2010, and will expand into the additional 135,000-square-foot space in the spring of 2011, upon development completion.

Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report October, 2010 sales/trading statement results on November 03, 2010.

Key Development Headline: LHC Group, Inc. Enter into a Joint Venture in Mount Vernon, Ky
Key Development Situation: LHC Group Inc. announced that it has entered into a joint venture in Mount Vernon, Ky. Terms of the deal with Rockcastle Regional Hospital and Respiratory Care Center were not revealed. The company also acquired the home health assets of the Livingston Hospital and Health Services in Salem, Ky., and the assets of North Idaho Home Health at Coeur D'Alene, Idaho. Terms of those agreements also were not revealed.

Key Development Headline: LHC Group, Inc. Enters into Home Health Joint Venture with Rockcastle Regional Hospital and Respiratory Care Center, to Provide Home Health Services in Rockcastle County
Key Development Situation: LHC Group, Inc. announced that it has entered into a home health joint venture with Rockcastle Regional Hospital and Respiratory Care Center, located in Mount Vernon, Kentucky to provide home health services in Rockcastle County in the Certificate of Need (CON) state of Kentucky. The primary service area of these acquisitions covers six counties in Kentucky and Idaho, with an estimated population of approximately 253,000 and almost 15% over the age of 65. Combined annual net revenues for the agencies in 2009 were approximately $2.6 million.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation to Settle Drug-Supply Charges for $77.6 Million
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation's pharmacy unit agreed to pay $77.6 million to settle charges that it was lax in limiting sales of pseudoephedrine, which can be used to make methamphetamine. Under the agreement, CVS will pay a $75 million civil fine and forfeit $2.6 million in profits from the sales. "Between September 2007 and November 2008, CVS supplied large amounts of pseudoephedrine to methamphetamine traffickers in Southern California, and the company's illegal sales led directly to an increase in methamphetamine production in California". As part the agreement, the government will not pursue criminal charges against CVS.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation to Cut 69 Jobs in Allegheny County
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation is preparing to lay off 69 people. The company filed a WARN notice with the state late last week of its plans for layoffs expected to take place by Dec. 3. The company reported layoffs are to take place in its offices in Monroeville, as well as in its mail services facility and IT building, both of which are in O'Hara Township.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Appoints Jonathan C. Roberts as PBM Chief Operating Officer
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced that it has appointed Jonathan C. Roberts as Chief Operating Officer of its pharmacy benefit management business. Roberts, who is currently Executive Vice President, Rx Purchasing, Pricing and Network Relations, will now also assume the leadership of PBM operations mail service pharmacy and specialty pharmacy. Roberts, 54, is an experienced health care executive and pharmacist. He joined CVS/pharmacy nearly 20 years ago and has served in a variety of leadership roles across the enterprise including Senior Vice President, Store Operations, CVS/pharmacy and Chief Information Officer, CVS Caremark.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Names David J. Brailer to Board of Directors
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that David J. Brailer, Chairman of Health Evolution Partners, has been elected to its board of directors. Brailer, who joins the board as an independent director, becomes the board's 11th member. Before his appointment, Brailer was a senior fellow at the Health Technology Center in San Francisco, a non-profit research and education organization that provides strategic information and resources to health care organizations about the future impact of technology in health care delivery.

Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report September, 2010 sales/trading statement results on October 05, 2010.

Key Development Headline: Universal Health Services Inc. Promotes John Cunningham to Vice President of Operations, Acute Division
Key Development Situation: Universal Health Services Inc. has promoted John Cunningham to vice president of operations, acute division. Cunningham had been vice president, supply chain operations of the hospital firm.

Key Development Headline: Texas Pharmacies File Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act Suit Against CVS Caremark
Key Development Situation: Six independent pharmacies in Texas are suing CVS Caremark Corporation for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act violations and trade secret misappropriation. The complaint also says CVS Caremark contracts requiring patients to buy maintenance medications only from CVS Caremark violate the Texas "Any Willing Provider" law. The suit claims CVS Caremark violates the firewall between the retail pharmacy and the pharmacy benefit manager entities as required when the Federal Trade Commission approved the CVS and Caremark 2007 merger. Instead, the combined company built an information technology platform that straddles all of CVS Caremark's business segments, capturing in-depth patient data for marketing and other purposes in violation of HIPAA patient privacy laws. The plaintiffs are board members of American Pharmacies. The American Pharmacies plaintiffs say patients report being forced, via higher copayments and refusal to cover maintenance medications, to leave their pharmacy where the patient and pharmacist have a long-time professional and personal relationship. Other patients report moving to a CVS Caremark network pharmacy out of fear of losing all health insurance coverage. The patients' physicians also are targeted to change prescribing practices to include drugs from CVS Caremark-favored drug makers. The plaintiffs are: Rogers Pharmacy, Victoria; Brookshire Bros. Pharmacy of Kirbyville; Hometown Pharmacy, Fairfield; Hibbs Pharmacy, Bay City; Kinsey's Pharmacy, Tyler; and De La Rosa Pharmacy, Weslaco.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Names Jeffrey Berkowitz as Senior Vice President of Pharmaceutical Development and Market Access
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that Jeffrey Berkowitz has joined the company as senior vice president of pharmaceutical development and market access. He will report to Kermit R. Crawford, president of Walgreens pharmacy services division. In this new position, Berkowitz will be responsible for the overall pharmacy contracting strategy for the company, both on the pharmaceutical manufacturing side and on the retail payer side. As a member of the senior management team, he will assume leadership for identifying and cultivating strategic external relationships and will oversee key initiatives with pharmaceutical manufacturers that will add to the company's growth. Berkowitz was most recently senior vice president of global market access for Merck & Company Inc. In that role, he was a member of the Merck Global Human Health Leadership Team.

Key Development Headline: Health Management Associates Inc. Attorneys Files Motion to Dismiss Lawsuit from a Former Executive
Key Development Situation: Attorneys for Health Management Associates Inc. have filed defense arguments and a motion to dismiss a lawsuit from a former executive who alleges the company in Naples submitted false Medicare claims and bribed doctors for patient referrals. The 25-page motion filed in federal court in Tampa essentially argues that Mike Mastej, the former chief executive officer of Physicians Regional Medical Center at Collier Boulevard, failed to provide the specifics of fraudulent Medicare claims required under the federal False Claims Act. Likewise, the defense says Mastej failed to show how violations of the anti-kickback law occurred between physicians and the hospitals directly as opposed to HMA, the indirect parent of the hospital, according to the court documents. Mastej filed the sealed lawsuit against his former employer in January alleging HMA officials induced physicians to refer patients to its Naples hospitals by making payments to them, disguised as payments for on-call services. The lawsuit was unsealed by a Tampa judge in August after the U.S. Department of Justice declined to join the complaint, after failing to complete its investigation after two time extensions.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Reports Unaudited Consolidated Earnings Results for the Fourth Quarter and Twelve Months Ended August 31, 2010; Expects New Store Openings in Fiscal 2011
Key Development Situation:
Walgreen Co. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and twelve months ended August 31, 2010. For the quarter, the company reported net earnings were $470 million or $0.49 per basic and diluted share on net sales of $16,870 million against net earnings were $436 million or $0.44 per basic and diluted share on net sales of $15,703 million for the same period a year ago. Operating income was $746 million compared to $702 million a year ago. Earnings before income tax provision was $728 million compared to $679 million a year ago. The double-digit increase in earnings per share was driven by strong operating performance across company's 7,500-store network and expense control companywide.

For the twelve months, the company reported net earnings were $2,091 million or $2.13 per basic share and $2.12 per diluted share on net sales of $67,420 million against net earnings were $2,006 million or $2.03 per basic share and $2.02 per diluted share on net sales of $63,335 million for the same period a year ago. Operating income was $3,458 million compared to $3,247 million a year ago. Earnings before income tax provision was $3,373 million compared to $3,164 million a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was $3,744 million compared to $4,111 million a year ago. Additions to property and equipment were $1,014 million compared to $1,927 million a year ago.

The company expects new store openings of between 2.5% and 3.0% in fiscal 2011.

Key Development Headline: Amedisys Inc. announces Restructural changes
Key Development Situation: Amedisys Inc. announced that it will be closing 13 agencies (nine Home Health and four Hospice) and consolidating another 26 locations (23 Home Health and three Hospice) into existing locations. The company also plans to reduce its start-up program, discontinuing the start-up process currently in progress associated with 28 prospective Home Health agencies and reducing its planned pipeline. As a result, the company expects to open five to 10 Home Health start-ups in 2011, down from the total 40 start-ups expected to be opened in 2010. As a result of these actions, the company expects to incur non-recurring charges in the range of $6 to $8 million in the third quarter and approximately $1 million in the fourth quarter of 2010. These charges include lease terminations of approximately $4 to $5 million and other charges, including severance payments, of approximately $3 to $4 million. These estimates are preliminary, and based on a number of assumptions and could change materially.

Key Development Headline: Universal Health Services Inc. Announces Resignation of Michael Marquez as Senior Vice President of the Company and as President of the Acute Care Division
Key Development Situation: Universal Health Services Inc. announced that Michael Marquez has resigned as Senior Vice President of the company and as President of the Acute care division. He plans to relocate to Florida for personal and family reasons. Mr. Marquez has served as President of the Acute care division since May 2009 and had previously served as Co-President of the Acute care division with Marc D. Miller. Until a replacement is named, Marc D. Miller, President of UHS, will assume interim responsibility for the Acute Care Division and will immediately commence a search for a permanent replacement.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Report August, 2010 Sales/Trading Statement Results on September 03, 2010
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report August, 2010 sales/trading statement results on September 03, 2010.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation to Pay $2.65 Million in Massachusetts Drug Costs
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation will pay $2.65 million to settle allegations that it overcharged Massachusetts municipalities for prescription drugs under the state's workers compensation insurance system. The settlement, filed last week in Suffolk Superior Court, covers $1.3 million in overcharges since 2002 that'll be reimbursed to 200 cities and towns. The remaining $1.35 million will go to the state's general fund. Municipalities, on average, will receive about $4,500 each, but the largest reimbursements include $61,865 for Boston, $52,434 for Brockton and $51,200 for Lowell. The settlement is part of an ongoing investigation by the attorney general's office into pharmacies' prescription overcharges under workers compensation.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Set to Cut 400 Jobs
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced that it will cut 400 jobs when it closes its Birmingham mail-order pharmacy Oct. 29, 2010. The pharmacy serves customers who choose not to go to a retail store or whose drug plan mandates automated postal refills, which the industry says saves money.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Cut Up to 150 Accounting Jobs
Key Development Situation: As many as 150 accounting jobs could be eliminated at Walgreen Co.'s Deerfield headquarters within the next 10 months as the drugstore giant outsources the work. The job losses result from Walgreen Co.'s agreement with Genpact, to take over certain accounting work. Genpact has acquired Walgreen's accounting office in Danville, Ill., where 500 former Walgreen employees have become employees of Genpact. Another 300 Walgreen jobs, including the 150 in Deerfield, will be affected by the move. The remaining 150 jobs are scattered among Walgreen accounting offices nationwide. An unspecified number of Walgreen accounting department employees who remain employed will be shifted to other jobs or see their positions changed. The initiative has already resulted in 50 jobs eliminated in Walgreen's Information Technology department.

Key Development Headline: Former Executive of Physicians Regional Medical Center Files Whistleblower Lawsuit against Health Management Associates Inc
Key Development Situation: The former executive of Physicians Regional Medical Center at Collier Boulevard has filed a whistleblower lawsuit against Health Management Associates Inc. that says the hospital chain illegally induced physicians with money and favors in exchange for patients referrals, according to the complaint unsealed last week in federal court in Tampa. The lawsuit was filed under seal in January by Michael Mastej, the former CEO of the 100-bed hospital when it opened in February 2007. He was terminated eight months later in October 2007. The lawsuit says HMA officials engaged in the unlawful actions since early 2007, at least, and continuing to the present time, by accepting Medicare patient referrals after offering inducements to physicians in violation of federal anti-kickback laws. HMA also violated federal Medicare reimbursement regulations when it received payment for treating the patients based on the unlawful referrals. Although the lawsuit says the unlawful conduct began in early 2007, the complaint also says HMA's cost reports to the federal government from early 1990 to the present included services to patients whose physicians had received kickbacks or illegal inducements. The Department of Justice was investigating the complaint after it was filed in January and was granted two extensions for making a decision whether to become a party in the case. The Justice Department could not complete its investigation by a July 29 deadline and filed a motion that it would not join in the case. That led to the judge's decision to unseal the complaint.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Report July, 2010 Sales/Trading Statement Results on August 04, 2010
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report July, 2010 sales/trading statement results on August 04, 2010.

Key Development Headline: Berman DeValerio Files Securities Class Action Against Amedisys
Key Development Situation: Berman DeValerio filed a securities fraud lawsuit against Amedisys Inc. and certain of its top officials. The complaint was filed on behalf of investors who purchased or otherwise acquired publicly traded Amedisys securities between April 30, 2008 and July 12, 2010 and were damaged by the conduct asserted therein. The action seeks to recover losses under Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. Pursuant to the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, investors wishing to serve as the Lead Plaintiff are required to file a motion for appointment as Lead Plaintiff by no later than August 9, 2010.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Gets 12-Year Contract with Aetna
Key Development Situation: Aetna Inc. and CVS Caremark Corporation announced a deal for Aetna to contract out its Pharmacy Benefit Management (PBM) services to CVS, starting Jan. 1 of 2011. Under the 12-year agreement, which must still meet regulatory approval, CVS will serve approximately 9.7 million Aetna PBM members and administer approximately $9.5 billion in annual drug spending. Financial terms weren't disclosed. The deal calls for Aetna to transfer about 800 PBM employees to CVS while retaining another 1,000 PBM employees. Aetna will continue to manage clinical programs, protocols and oversight of its pharmacy benefits business.

Key Development Headline: Bernstein Liebhard LLP Files Class Action Suit Against Amedisys, Inc
Key Development Situation: Bernstein Liebhard LLP announced that it filed a class action in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana on behalf of purchasers of Amedisys Inc. securities during the period of August 2, 2005 and June 30, 2010, inclusive the 'Class Period'. Defendants are Amedisys and certain of its officers and executives. The complaint charges Amedisys and certain of its officers and executives with violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The complaint alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements, as well as failed to disclose material adverse facts about the company's business, operations, and prospects. Specifically, the complaint alleges that defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose: (1) that the company's reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme whereby the company intentionally increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system, as those excess visits were not always medically necessary, (2) that the company's reported sales and earnings were inflated by said scheme and subject to recoupment by Medicare, (3) that the company was in material violation of its Code of Ethical Business Conduct and compliance due to the scheme to inflate Medicare revenues and (4) based on the foregoing, defendants lacked a basis for their positive statements about the Company, its prospects and growth. Plaintiffs seek to recover damages on behalf of all Class members who purchased or otherwise acquired securities of Amedisys during the Class Period.

Key Development Headline: Health Management Associates, Inc. Appoints Alan Levine as Senior Vice President of Health Development Operations and Government Relations
Key Development Situation: Health Management Associates Inc. announced it has appointed Alan Levine as its new senior vice president of health development operations and government relations effective August 9, 2010. Alan is a 19 year veteran of the health care industry, most recently serving as Secretary of the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals and Senior Health Policy Advisor to Governor Bobby Jindal. In this role, he oversaw a $7 billion annual budget and a wide range of state operations, including hospitals and institutions serving health and human services needs, Medicaid, public health, emergency response and health policy.

Key Development Headline: Trustmark Selects CVS Caremark Corporation as Pharmacy Benefits Manager for Group Clients
Key Development Situation: Trustmark has entered into an agreement with CVS Caremark Corporation to provide pharmacy benefits management services to all its small group, large group and association fully-insured and self-funded clients effective July 1, 2010. CVS Caremark was chosen because of its excellent customer service, exceptional savings for members and its shared philosophy of being personal, flexible and trusted. The relationship offers great service, convenience and savings for Trustmark group health plan members. Through CVS Caremark, members will have access to more than 64,000 pharmacies nationwide. Plus, plan members can benefit from a number of valuable programs, including savings on generics, FastStart(R) mail service, MinuteClinic(R) locations and specialty pharmacy services. Through a password-protected site on Caremark.com, members can check their benefit coverage, verify drug costs, view their prescription history, order prescription refills, and sign-up for alerts that share cost savings and health improvement information. In addition, Caremark.com is now mobile friendly, allowing members to manage their prescriptions through any mobile device. Trustmark members were successfully transitioned to Caremark on July 1 with no disruption to their pharmacy service.

Key Development Headline: Bernstein Liebhard LLP Files Class Action on Behalf of Investors in Amedisys, Inc
Key Development Situation: Bernstein Liebhard LLP announced that a class action has been filed in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana on behalf of purchasers of Amedisys Inc. common stock during the period of April 30, 2008 and June 30, 2010, inclusive Defendants are Amedisys and certain of its officers and executives. The complaint charges Amedisys and certain of its officers and executives with violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Amedisys is a provider of home health services to the chronic, co-morbid, aging American population. The company operates in two segments: home health and hospice segments. The Complaint alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements, as well as failed to disclose material adverse facts about the company's business, operations, and prospects. Specifically, the Complaint alleges that defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose: that the company's reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme whereby the company intentionally increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system, as those excess visits were not always medically necessary; that the company's reported sales and earnings were inflated by the scheme and subject to recoupment by Medicare; that the company was in material violation of its Code of Ethical Business Conduct and compliance due to the scheme to inflate Medicare revenues; and (4) based on the foregoing, defendants lacked a basis for their positive statements about the company, its prospects and growth.

Key Development Headline: Kaplan Fox Files Securities Class Action on Behalf of Purchasers of Amedisys Inc. Common Stock
Key Development Situation: Kaplan Fox & Kilsheimer LLP has filed a class action suit against Amedisys Inc., William F. Borne, the company's Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Directors, and Dale E. Redman, the company's Chief Financial Officer that alleges violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 on behalf of purchasers of company's common stock during the period between April 30, 2008 and June 30, 2010, inclusive. The case is pending in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana and has been assigned docket No. 3:10-cv-00464-BAJ-DLD. A copy of the complaint may be obtained from Kaplan Fox or the Court. The Complaint alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants reported "record" financial results, but failed to disclose that the company improperly increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system; as a result of the company's improper conduct, its reported sales and earnings were materially inflated; and based on the foregoing, defendants lacked a basis for their positive statements about the Company, its prospects and growth.

Key Development Headline: Kahn Swick & Foti, LLC Files Securities Class Action Lawsuit Against Amedisys
Key Development Situation: Kahn Swick & Foti, LLC (KSF) announced that investors have only until August 9, 2010 to inquire and take advantage of their right to apply for lead plaintiff in a securities class action lawsuit filed in the United States District Court, Middle District of Louisiana against Amedisys Inc. and certain of its top officials. No class has yet been certified in this action.

Key Development Headline: Charles H. Johnson & Associates Announces Filing of Securities Class Action against Amedisys, Inc
Key Development Situation: Charles H. Johnson & Associates announced that a class action has been commenced in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana on behalf of purchasers of Amedisys Inc. publicly traded securities during the period February 23, 2010 through May 13, 2010. The complaint alleges that defendants made misleading statements and failed to disclose: 1) that the company's reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme whereby the company intentionally increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system, as those excess visits were not always medically necessary; 2) that the company's reported sales and earnings were inflated by said scheme and subject to recoupment by Medicare; and 3) that the company was in material violation of its Code of Ethical Business Conduct and compliance due to the scheme to inflate Medicare revenues.

Key Development Headline: Kendall Law Group Investigates LHC Group, Inc. for Shareholders
Key Development Situation: Kendall Law Group is investigating certain officers and directors of the LHC Group for possible breaches of fiduciary duty and other federal and state laws. The firm's investigation seeks to determine whether LHC and its directors and officers breached their fiduciary duties by causing or allowing it to unfairly take advantage of the Medicare reimbursement system.

Accordingly, on June 30, 2010, Mr. Sabel retired from his position as employee Chairman of the Board of the company. Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. to Report June, 2010 Sales/Trading Statement Results on July 06, 2010
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. announced that they will report June, 2010 sales/trading statement results on July 06, 2010.

Key Development Headline: Bernstein Liebhard LLP Files Class Action Suit on Behalf of Investors in Amedisys, Inc
Key Development Situation: Bernstein Liebhard LLP announced that a class action has been filed in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana on behalf of purchasers of Amedisys Inc. securities during the period of February 23, 2010 and May 13, 2010, inclusive. The allegations in the complaint, described below, are further corroborated by Amedisys' announcement on June 30, 2010, that it had received notice of a formal investigation from the Securities and Exchange Commission pertaining to the company, and received a subpoena for documents relating to matters under review by the Senate Finance Committee. The complaint charges Amedisys and certain of its officers and executives with violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Amedisys is a provider of home health services to the chronic, co-morbid, aging American population. The company operates in two segments: home health and hospice segments. The Complaint alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements, as well as failed to disclose material adverse facts about the company's business, operations, and prospects. Specifically, the Complaint alleges that defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose: that the company's reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme whereby the company intentionally increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system, as those excess visits were not always medically necessary; that the company's reported sales and earnings were inflated by said scheme and subject to recoupment by Medicare; that the company was in material violation of its Code of Ethical Business Conduct and compliance due to the scheme to inflate Medicare revenues; and (4) based on the foregoing, defendants lacked a basis for their positive statements about the company, its prospects and growth. Plaintiffs seek to recover damages on behalf of all Class members who purchased or otherwise acquired securities of Amedisys during the Class Period.

Key Development Headline: Kendall Law Group Investigates Amedisys Inc. for Shareholders
Key Development Situation: Kendall Law Group is investigating certain officers and directors of Amedisys Inc. for possible breaches of fiduciary duty and other federal and state laws. The national securities firm seeks to determine whether the company and its directors and officers breached their fiduciary duties by causing or allowing it to unfairly take advantage of the Medicare reimbursement system. Shareholders familiar with the investigation are urged to contact the Kendall Law Group.

Key Development Headline: Finkelstein Thompson LLP Announces Investigation of Amedisys, Inc
Key Development Situation: Finkelstein Thompson LLP announces that a class action lawsuit has been filed in the Middle District of Louisiana against Amedisys Inc. The complaint alleges that Amedisys failed to disclose that its reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme whereby the company intentionally increased in-home visits to patients to a level above and beyond that which was medically necessary, so as to trigger higher reimbursement rates from Medicare. The complaint further alleges this scheme had the effect of artificially inflating Amedisys's sales and earnings.

Key Development Headline: Ryan & Maniskas, LLP Announces Class Action Lawsuit Against Amedisys, Inc
Key Development Situation: Ryan & Maniskas, LLP announced that a class action lawsuit has been filed in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana on behalf of purchasers of the common stock of Amedisys Inc. during the period between February 23, 2010 and May 13, 2010, inclusive. The complaint, seeking to pursue remedies under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, charges that defendants failed to disclose during the Class Period the following: that the company's reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme (going back as far as 2006 perhaps) whereby defendants intentionally increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system, as those excess visits were not always medically necessary; that the company's reported sales and earnings were inflated by defendants' scheme and subject to recoupment by Medicare; that the company was in material violation of its Code of Ethical Business Conduct and compliance due to defendants' scheme to inflate Medicare revenues; and based on the foregoing, defendants lacked a basis for their positive statements about the company, its prospects and growth.

Key Development Headline: The Shuman Law Firm Investigates Amedisys Inc
Key Development Situation: The Shuman Law Firm announced that it is investigating potential breaches of fiduciary duty by certain officers and directors at Amedisys Inc. Amedisys provides home health and hospice services, including skilled nursing and home health aide services, physical, occupational and speech therapy, and medically oriented social work to individuals who require ongoing care. The investigation concerns allegations that the company has been taking advantage of the Medicare reimbursement system by increasing the number of in-home therapy visits to their clients, some of which were allegedly not medically necessary.

The complaint charges that Amedisys and certain of its officers and executives violated federal securities laws. Specifically, the complaint alleges that defendants made misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that the company's reported sales and earnings growth were materially impacted by a scheme whereby the company intentionally increased the number of in-home therapy visits to patients for the purpose of triggering higher reimbursement rates under the Medicare home health prospective payment system, as those excess visits were not always medically necessary; that the company's reported sales and earnings were inflated by said scheme and subject to recoupment by Medicare; and that the company was in material violation of its Code of Ethical Business Conduct and compliance due to the scheme to inflate Medicare revenues.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Launches Prescription Text Alerts and New Mobile Enhancements

Walgreens has also re-launched its iPhone application and mobile site, m.walgreens.com. New Walgreens mobile features include Prescription Text Alerts; Special Offer Texts; iPhone Application. iPhone users can take advantage of new features and functionality in the iPhone application. These include Photo account registration; browse products and check their in-store availability; view prescription history; one-touch GPS store locator; and Android/Blackberry Mobile Website Application.

Key Development Headline: Two Employees Files Lawsuit against HCA, Inc
Key Development Situation: Two employees of HCA, Inc. say the company violated federal labor law by expecting them to work during unpaid meal breaks. Christina Gonzales and Sean Smith filed a lawsuit in Nashville's U.S. District Court that seeks national class action status, as well as collective action status for other non-exempt HCA employees in the two states where they worked. Gonzales worked in the cardiac unit of Northeast Methodist Hospital outside San Antonio until October 2009, and Smith is employed at Menorah Medical Center in Overland Park, Kansas. Both claim they were routinely expected to remain at their posts during 30-minute meal breaks, even though the hospitals' computerized time and attendance system automatically deducts the time from their shifts.

Key Development Headline: Pomerantz Haudek Grossman & Gross Files Class Action Lawsuit against Amedisys
Key Development Situation: Pomerantz Haudek Grossman & Gross LLP has filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court, Middle District of Louisiana against Amedisys Inc. and certain of its top officials. The class action (Civil Action No. 3:10-cv-00395-RET-CN) was filed on behalf of purchasers of Amedisys securities between February 23, 2010 and May 13, 2010, both dates inclusive, (the "Class Period"). The Complaint alleges violations of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 promulgated there under.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Ends CVS Caremark Corporation Network Relationship
Key Development Situation: Walgreen Co. said it will no longer do business with CVS Caremark's pharmacy benefits management operation because it wants better prices and objects to policies designed to drive customers toward CVS stores. The decision does not affect current Caremark contracts, but if Walgreen stands by the move, it won't handle any Caremark-managed prescriptions in about three years. Walgreen said it will not participate in new or renewed Caremark plans starting June 7, 2010. The company said it is giving up billions of dollars in revenue with the move, although the full effects won't be felt for a few years. CVS said it was "surprised and disappointed" by the decision and had recently discussed these subjects with Walgreen's management. It said it is open to additional talks but added that Walgreen is trying to squeeze Caremark into giving better reimbursement rates. Walgreen singled out CVS's Maintenance Choice program for criticism. Maintenance Choice is a major program through which Caremark beneficiaries can either pick up 90-day prescriptions at CVS pharmacies or get them delivered through the mail. The program is for patients with chronic illnesses who need regular supplies of medications.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Announces Board Appointments; Appoints Ernst & Young LLP as Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm for 2010; Adopts Amendment of the Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation
Key Development Situation:
On May 12, 2010, CVS Caremark Corporation held its 2010 Annual Meeting of Stockholders. At the Annual Meeting, the company Edwin M. Banks, C. David Brown II, David W. Dorman, Kristen Gibney Williams, Marian L. Heard, William H. Joyce, Jean-Pierre Millon, Terrence Murray, C.A. Lance Piccolo, Sheli Z. Rosenberg, Thomas M. Ryan and Richard J. Swift as board directors for a term of one year. 

The company also appointed Ernst & Young LLP as the company’s independent registered public accounting firm for 2010. 
 
 At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the corporation on March 10, 2010, resolutions were duly adopted approving the amendment of the Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation of the Corporation and declaring said amendment to be advisable. The proposed amendment was as follows: Article 9th of the Corporation’s Certificate of Incorporation is hereby amended to read in its entirety as Special meetings of the stockholders may be called (i) by the Board of Directors, the Chairman of the Board of Directors or the Chief Executive Officer of the Corporation or (ii) upon written request from holders of record of at least 25% of the voting power of the outstanding capital stock of the Corporation entitled to vote on the matter or matters to be brought before the proposed special meeting, filed with the Secretary of the Corporation and otherwise in accordance with the By-laws, and may not be called by any other person or persons. Notwithstanding the foregoing, whenever holders of one or more classes or series of Preferred Stock or Preference Stock shall have the right, voting separately as a class or series, to elect directors, such holders may call, to the extent provided in Article FOURTH, special meetings of holders of such Preferred Stock or Preference Stock.

Key Developments by Type: Executive/Board Changes - Other; Executive Changes - CEO
Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Announces Executive Changes
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced that Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer Thomas M. Ryan will retire from his position as Chief Executive Officer of the Company at next year's Annual Meeting of Shareholders in May 2011. The Board of Directors is appointing Larry J. Merlo, 54, as President and Chief Operating Officer, and anticipates Mr. Merlo will succeed Mr. Ryan as CEO. Mr. Merlo, a seasoned executive with 31 years of experience including 20 with CVS, is also being elected to the Company's Board of Directors. Effective immediately, Mr. Merlo will assume additional responsibilities, including Human Resources, Legal, Corporate Compliance and Government Relations. He most recently served as Executive Vice President of the Company and President of its CVS/pharmacy retail operations, overseeing a portfolio of more than 7,000 CVS/pharmacy locations with net revenues of over $55 billion. The Company is initiating a search for Mr. Merlo's successor as President of the CVS/pharmacy retail operations, considering both internal and external candidates. Mr. Merlo will continue to hold this responsibility until a successor is chosen.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Launches Program to Help Pharmacy Benefit Management Clients Improve Diabetes Care
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced the launch of a new program aimed at strengthening pharmacy care for diabetes patients by improving member engagement through enhanced interactions with their pharmacists. The program is being offered to the company's pharmacy benefit management (PBM) clients for implementation in 2011 based on positive results from a recently completed pilot. In addition to achieving significant improvements in medication adherence rates and closing gaps in care, preliminary data also suggests the program can save employers on their health care benefit costs, with an estimated annual savings of nearly $600 per member with diabetes. In general, a client with 50,000 employees whose population has an average prevalence of diabetes could save approximately $3.3 million a year, or up to $6 million a year if there is a high prevalence of the disease. The six-month pilot of the Pharmacy Advisor(TM) program was conducted in partnership with a large global steel company in which participating members with diabetes achieved significant improvements in closing gaps in care and medication adherence rates. The pilot program used a multi-step process to identify and counsel members about gaps in care and adherence issues. Results demonstrated that this process closed a significantly higher number of gaps in care compared to a control group who were not counseled (58% and 90% higher for phone and face-to-face counseling, respectively). In addition, members receiving counseling were more likely to be adherent in every targeted medication class. The Pharmacy Advisor program integrates the benefits of the PBM and the retail pharmacy to improve pharmacy care. The program applies industry-leading health information technology to identify members who are being treated for diabetes and engages them with highly targeted counseling and support through the channels they choose. Member outreach includes educational information, pharmacist-initiated phone calls, or face-to-face counseling with a pharmacist at a local CVS/pharmacy. In addition, evidence-based protocols are applied to review the member's current treatment and determine if there are gaps in care or issues with medication adherence. Members are also presented with options and solutions to enable them to get the most out of their pharmacy benefit and identify opportunities for cost savings. The company plans to expand Pharmacy Advisor program offerings to include other chronic diseases and types of interventions in the near future.

Key Development Headline: CVS Caremark Corporation Presents Data of Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy
Key Development Situation: CVS Caremark Corporation announced that it presented data at the 22nd Annual Meeting of the Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) that illustrate successful methods for improving adherence to medication and lowering prescription drug costs. The company showed results from three studies which demonstrated the positive impact of various tools available to pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) - including automated telephonic messaging, fax alerts to physicians about gaps in care, and strategic co-pay waivers for generic medications. One of the CVS Caremark studies examined the effectiveness of Interactive Voice Response (IVR) programs in improving persistency to maintenance medication therapies dispensed via mail-service pharmacy. From October 2008 to February 2009, more than 94,000 commercially-insured mail pharmacy users received various combinations of supportive adherence messages delivered by IVR. Results showed that among members who answered the telephonic IVR, odds of refilling the prescription were up to 70.6% higher than controls. In addition, among members receiving early refill reminders the average first fill persistency rate (FFPR) at mail was 3.5% higher than controls, while the average FFPR was 1.4% higher than controls for members receiving refill reminders after their drug supply was exhausted. A second study examined the effectiveness of faxed alerts to physicians in resolving potential gaps in therapy in three areas: 1) adding an osteoporosis-preventative agent for women on long-term glucocorticosteroids; 2) adding an ACE inhibitor or ARB for adults with hypertension and diabetes; and 3) adding a lipid-lowering agent for individuals 30 years or older with diabetes. During the study period, a total of 337 employers and health plans, representing more than five million members, participated in a program that delivered fax alerts to providers when members' pharmacy claims indicated the absence of a recommended therapy in one of the areas outlined above. In this study, interventions were conducted between January 1 and March 30, 2009, with gap closure rates measured through September 30, 2009. Results showed that gap closure rates among members whose physician received a fax alert, were significantly higher than controls. For those members whose claims triggered an osteoporosis alert, gap closure rates were 8.4 percentage points higher than controls, those who triggered an anti-hypertensive therapy alert had gap closure rates 5.5 percentage points higher and those who triggered a cholesterol management alert had gap closure rates 4.5 percentage points higher. A third study examined the effectiveness of generic co-pay waiver programs designed to provide incentives for members using brand medications to switch to generics. Members using targeted brands were given a six-month period during which they could change to a recommended generic medication and receive generic co-pay waivers at mail. Members who converted to a generic early in the six-month period received two generic co-pay waivers (i.e. on medication for six months). Members who delayed their generic conversion until the end of the six-month period received one generic co-pay waiver (i.e. on medication for three months). The study focused on members who continued therapy with the generic after using the co-pay waiver(s) and found an overall higher sustained generic dispensing rate (GDR) for members who received two co-pay waivers (GDR of 88.2%) compared to members who received one co-pay waiver (GDR of 71.7%).

Key Development Headline: HCA Reportedly Mulls IPO
Key Development Situation: HCA, Inc. might be considering an Initial Public Offering (IPO) in the coming months, a source familiar with the situation said. Bloomberg earlier reported, citing sources, that HCA is preparing for an IPO that may raise $3 billion, and plans to interview banks to underwrite the sale in the coming weeks. Reuters reported that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and Bain Capital, owners of HCA declined to comment and HCA did not return a phone call seeking comment.

Key Development Headline: HCA, Inc. Cuts 36 Employees
Key Development Situation: The Treasure Coast division of HCA, Inc. has let about 36 employees go as part of the latest round of corporate layoffs. The staff reductions at St. Lucie Medical Center in Port St. Lucie and Lawnwood Regional Medical Center & Heart Institute in Fort Pierce were focused on employees not considered directly involved with patient care. Those let go were given severance packages that varied depending upon the length of time the employee was with the center. The reductions -- 15 at St. Lucie Medical and 21 at Lawnwood -- were deemed necessary because of the overall economic health of HCA. Of the 21 positions eliminated at St. Lucie Medical, a few were through attrition. The reduction in staff comes as Lawnwood is seeking to fill about 33 nursing positions for the expansion of its Trauma Intensive Care Unit. The staff reductions follow the elimination of nine full-time employees, including one clinical nurse, at St. Lucie Medical Center in November 2009.

Key Development Headline: Walgreen Co. Announces a New 20,000-Square-Foot Office
Key Development Situation: Leopardo recently completed the interior construction of Walgreen Co.'s first-ever downtown offices. Walgreen Co.'s new 20,000-square-foot office space is located on the 4th floor of the Sullivan Center, which is being repositioned by Joseph Freed & Associates. The new space will house 65 employees who handle Walgreen's graphic and web design, marketing, information technology and merchandising.

Key Developments by Type: Announcements of Earnings; Corporate Guidance - New/Confirmed; Business Expansions
Key Development Headline: LHC Group, Inc. Announces Unaudited Consolidated Earnings Results for the Fourth Quarter and Full Year Ended December 31, 2009; Provides Earnings Guidance for the Year 2010; Plans to Open New Locations
Key Development Situation:
LHC Group, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2009. Net service revenue for the fourth quarter of 2009 increased 27.0% to $141.5 million compared with $111.4 million for the same period in 2008. Net income attributable to LHC Group for the fourth quarter of 2009 totaled $12.7 million, or $0.70 per diluted share, compared with net income of $10.5 million, or $0.58 per diluted share, for the fourth quarter of 2008. For the quarter, the company has reported operating income of $23.8 million, income from continuing operations before income taxes and non-controlling interest of $23.8 million and income from continuing operations of $15.8 million or $0.70 per diluted share compared to operating income of $20.8 million, income from continuing operations before income taxes and non-controlling interest of $21.2 million and income from continuing operations of $15 million or $0.60 per diluted share reported last year.

Net service revenue for the year ended December 31, 2009, increased 39.0% to $532.0 million compared with $382.6 million in 2008. Net income attributable to LHC Group for the year ended December 31, 2009, totaled $43.8 million, or $2.43 per diluted share, compared with net income of $30.2 million, or $1.69 per diluted share, for the year ended December 31, 2008. For the year, the company has reported operating income of $85.0 million, income from continuing operations before income taxes and non-controlling interest of $84.6 million and income from continuing operations of $58 million or $2.43 per diluted share compared to operating income of $60.5 million, income from continuing operations before income taxes and non-controlling interest of $61.5 million and income from continuing operations of $42.7 million or $1.73 per diluted share reported last year. Net cash provided by operating activities were $49.2 million against $85.5 million and expenditure on purchases of property, building, and equipment was $8.2 million against $8.5 million reported last year.

The Company also announced their net revenue and fully diluted earnings per share guidance for full-year 2010. Full-year net service revenue is expected to be in the range of $610 million to $620 million and fully diluted earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $2.60 to $2.70. The guidance does not take into account any future acquisitions. 

In 2010, the company anticipates opening 25 to 30 new de novo locations, which has not been factored into the 2010 guidance.
